title: Construction workers march through Adelaide to demand industrial manslaughter laws
text:
Hundreds of construction workers have marched through Adelaide to demand new workplace laws, following the deaths of tradies on sites.

Members of CFMEU SA stopped working at building sites across the city on Wednesday to participate in the protest calling for industrial manslaughter laws.

The protesters are demanding jail sentences for employers whose workers are killed on the job due to safety breaches.

Construction workers donned dark shades and gold chains during a march on Wednesday

Members of CFMEU SA are calling for industrial manslaughter laws, following the deaths of workers on sites

Hundreds of demonstrators left work on Wednesday morning to participate in the march

Hundreds of demonstrators descended on Victoria Square from 10.30am to march to Parliament House.

Dressed in his-vis work gear and displaying CFMEU logos and flags, the group blocked traffic flow as they chanted 'kill a worker, go to jail'.

One protester dressed in a 'we built this city' CFMEU t-shirt was photographed pumping his fist into the air during a chant.

CFMEU Victorian secretary John Setka, who resigned from the Labor party on Wednesday, also participated in the rally.

The rally also heard from families who have lost loved ones on the job.

One protester dressed in a 'we built this city' CFMEU t-shirt was photographed pumping his fist into the air during a chant

Dressed in his-vis and displaying CFMEU logos and flags, protesters ditched their work sites on Wednesday

In a statement on Facebook, CFMEU SA said: 'Every day, our organisers try to make work sites safer in an industry where too many builders blatantly ignore safety laws and put workers' lives at risk.'

'They know that if somebody dies the worst outcome they face is a fine. Excuses on safety have been offered for too long.

'It's time for strong industrial manslaughter laws and prosecutions to go with them to force change in our industry.'
